page.title: 06Architecture
page.content: Bildeston has a great variety of country town styles of housing through the centuries, the size and type of materials corresponding to the wealth of the village at that time. Most of the houses in the old part of the village, probably named Bildeston Street on the old Pedlar's way, were built in the late fifteenth and sixteenth centuries. The houses show various changes as the years have gone by, with the exposure of oak beams being a twentieth century style. Some overhanging beams were made flush by brick infill in the 19th century. The Georgian homes are of red and cream brick with slate roofs. Only the slate needs to be brought far, as there were local brick works supplying all styles and colours. Later victorian buildings are on the whole smaller and not very memorable.
